With only 2 high-quality products out of 8, the probability of a high-quality product is actually 2/8 = 0.25, but that's a binomial distribution. However, since we're only getting the product quality after the decision, we can use Bayes' theorem to update the probability. Let's assume the probability of a high-quality product is p. We have 2 high-quality products and 6 low-quality products. The probability of a high-quality product given that we got 2 high-quality products out of 8 is (2/8) / p. The probability of getting 2 high-quality products out of 8 given p is (8 choose 2) * p^2 * (1-p)^6. Using Bayes' theorem, we get p = (2/8) / ((8 choose 2) * p^2 * (1-p)^6).
